10.1016/j.mcat.2024.114152 Fig. 1 (a) The most stable atomic structure of TM@Mo4/3B2O2. (b) The formation energy diagram of different TM@Mo4/3B2O2. Fig 1 Fig. 2 The four most stable different O2 adsorption structures of (a) Ta@Mo4/3B2O2 (side-on); (b) Co@Mo4/3B2O2 (end-on); (c) Mo@Mo4/3B2O2 (dissociation); and (d) Pd@Mo4/3B2O2 (physical adsorption). Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) Bond lengths and polarized charges of O2 adsorbed on TM@Mo4/3B2O2. (b) Summary of adsorption structures of 25 elements. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) The first ORR reaction pathway (Normal ORR reaction). (b) Structural diagram of reaction process with Ni@Mo4/3B2O2 as an example. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) The second ORR reaction pathway (O2 dissociation). (b) Structural diagram of reaction process with Nb@Mo4/3B2O2 and Mo@Mo4/3B2O2. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) The third ORR reaction pathway (OOH dissociation). (b) Structural diagram of reaction process with Ta@Mo4/3B2O2 as an example. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a) The fourth ORR reaction pathway (OHOH dissociation). (b) Structural diagram of reaction process with Mn@Mo4/3B2O2 as an example. Fig 7 Fig. 8 (a) Taking Zn@Mo4/3B2O2 as an example, the fifth ORR reaction path (produce H2O2) and the structure diagram of the reaction process. (b) Summary of 6 ORR reaction paths on 25 SACs. Exploring earth-abundant and inexpensive electrocatalysts to realize efficient oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is urgently desired. In this work, through first-principles calculations, we have strategically designed a series of single-atom catalysts (SACs) for ORR by immobilizing single atoms on the surface of Mo4/3B2O2, denoted as TM@Mo4/3B2O2 (TM representing 3d, 4d, and 5d transition metal atoms, excluding Tc and Hg). Significantly, for 4e− ORR, the best catalyst was Co@Mo4/3B2O2 and Ru@Mo4/3B2O2, with an overpotential of 0.61 V and 0.63 V, close to the commonly used Pt catalyst (0.45 V). In 2e− ORR, Zn@Mo4/3B2O2 had the best catalytic activity, with a ΔG*OOH of -2.47 eV, close to the commonly used Pd catalyst (ΔG*OOH = -3.17 eV). By calculating the electronic properties of SACs, it was found that the number of electrons gained by the intermediate *O2 and *OOH from the SACs determines the O2 adsorption structures and ORR reaction pathways. In addition, there are two descriptors: ICOHP and a composition descriptor which provides atomic-level insights, that were found to summarize the ORR activity rules. Our work enriches the applications of the MBenes family in catalysis, and provides feasible guidance for the design of low-cost and high-effect ORR catalysts. Introduction With the escalating demand for energy and the increasingly prominent environmental issues, the pursuit of sustainable and environmentally friendly energy technologies has attracted widespread attention in recent years [1–5]. Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) have become promising competitors for various portable power applications due to their excellent energy conversion efficiency, simple structural design and rapid start-up capability at room temperature. The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) serves as a crucial half-reaction in PEMFCs, with its efficiency largely determining the catalytic performance [6]. To date, the most effective commercial catalyst for ORR remains the Pt/C metal. However, the scarcity and high cost of precious Pt metal have seriously hindered its widespread practical application [7]. Therefore, seeking non-precious metal alternatives is an urgent and arduous challenge. To overcome this issue, substantial theoretical and experimental efforts have focused on the design and exploration of novel electrocatalytic materials, including transition metal carbides/nitrides [8–11], metal oxides [12–15], graphene [16,17], nanowires [18,19], nanoparticles [20], nanoclusters [21], perovskites [22,23], and two-dimensional (2D) metal-organic frameworks [24,25]. In 2017, Sun et al. [26] first reported a novel two-dimensional transition metal boride, termed MBenes, which have a structure similar to that of two-dimensional transition metal carbonitrides (MXenes). Similarly, MBenes have excellent conductivity, fast charge transfer, tunable chemical surface area, and large specific surface area, making them highly promising for applications in energy storage and conversion [27,28]. Furthermore, a unique design strategy that single metal atoms are immobilized on supports to form single-atom catalysts (SACs) has achieved remarkable success in seeking low cost and high efficiency 2D electrocatalytic materials [29,30]. SACs, characterized by metal active sites that are atomically dispersed on suitable substrates, exhibit extremely high atom-utilization efficiency, thereby reducing the usage of precious metals. Additionally, the unique electronic structure and unsaturated coordination environments of the active center in SACs are beneficial for enhancing the adsorption ability of the reaction intermediates, thereby improving the catalytic activity [31–35]. Specifically, it has been demonstrated that MBenes possess superb physical and chemical characteristics, which are highly desired as substrates for SACs. Up till now, MBenes have been widely studied as catalysts or substrates of various reactions, including hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [26], oxygen reduction/evolution reaction (ORR/OER) [1,2,36,37] and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [3,38]. In the mechanism of ORR, individual diverse materials typically display distinct O2 adsorption structures and different ORR reaction pathways. However, there is little research explaining these variations from the perspective of electron transfer. In addition, accelerating the discovery of materials with excellent catalytic activity is of paramount importance and requires faster and more effective methods than traditional trial-and-error methods. In ORR research, the Gibbs free energy of the intermediate *O (ΔG*O) is commonly used as a descriptor to measure catalytic activity [32,39]. However, when extended to different matrix materials, its accuracy and universality are compromised. Therefore, it is urgent to explore an intrinsic descriptor that can accurately characterize the catalytic activity of different materials. Inspired by the SACs, through first-principles calculations, we have strategically designed a series of SACs for ORR by immobilizing single atoms on the surface of Mo4/3B2O2, denoted as TM@Mo4/3B2O2 (TM representing 3d, 4d, and 5d transition metal atoms, excluding Tc and Hg). Our research indicated that these 25 SACs exhibit four different types of O2 adsorption structures and six unique ORR reaction pathways. Especially Co@Mo4/3B2O2 exhibited the optimal activity in 4e− ORR and Zn@Mo4/3B2O2 exhibited the most superior activity in 2e− ORR. In addition, the exploration of electron transfer indicated that the amount of electron transfer from SACs to intermediates *O2 determines the adsorption structure of O2, while the amount of electron transfer from SACs to intermediates *OOH determines the ORR reaction pathway. Importantly, there are two key indicators that can summarize the rules controlling ORR activity. Our research contributes to a deeper understanding of the catalytic activity of the MBenes and provides valuable insights for designing economically efficient and sustainable ORR catalysts. Computational methodology The spin-polarized first-principles DFT calculations for all the SACs were performed through the projector augmented wave (PAW) method as implemented in the VASP code [40]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [41] of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [42] functional was applied to describe the electron exchange-correlation interactions. The cutoff energy was set to 500 eV and the k-points grid was sampled using a 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack mesh for structural optimization and a denser 7 × 7 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack mesh for electronic structure and static self-consistent calculations. In all calculations, a 25 Å vacuum distance in the z-direction was set to avoid interlayer interactions, and the van der Waals interaction was considered by using the empirical correction DFT-D3 approach [43]. The convergence tolerance for force and energy on each atom during the structure optimization was set to 1.0 × 10−5 eV/atom and 0.02 eV/Å, respectively. The thermal stability of SACs structures were evaluated by performing ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations, which lasted for 5 ps with a time step of 1.0 fs at 300 K. The formation energy (Ef) of transition metals (TM) embedded in the Mo4/3B2O2 hollow can be calculated by the following formula: (1) E f = E TM + S − E S − E TM In this formula, ETM+S and ES represent the total energies of TM@Mo4/3B2O2 and Mo4/3B2O2, respectively, and ETM represents the energy of per TM atom in the metal bulk with the most stable crystal structures. In acidic solution environments, the overall ORR occurring at the cathode can be summarized as O 2 ( g ) + 4 H + + 4 e − → 2 H 2 O , consisting of the following four-step elementary reaction: (2) O 2 ( g ) + H + + e − + * → * OOH (3) * OOH + H + + e − → * O + H 2 O ( l ) (4) * O + H + + e − → * OH (5) * OH + H + + e − → H 2 O ( 1 ) + * where * represents the active site on the catalyst surface. g and l represent the corresponding gas phase and liquid phase, respectively. For ORR, the chemical potential of (H+ + e−) is regarded as that of 1/2 H2 by setting the standard potential as the reference potential, that is, μH+ + μe- = 0.5μH2, at U = 0 V and PH2 = 1 bar, according to the method proposed by Nørskov et al. [44] The free energy change from the initial state to the final state of each elementary reaction involving electron transfer can be calculated by: (6) Δ G = Δ E + Δ ZPE − T Δ S + Δ G pH + Δ G U ΔE is the total energy change of the reaction obtained from DFT calculations. ΔZPE and ΔS are the changes in zero-point energy and entropy, respectively. T is the temperature and was set to 298.15 K (room temperature) in this work. ΔGU = -neU is employed to represent the impact of electrical potential on free energy, where U is the applied electrode potential, e is the elementary charge and n is the number of transferred proton-electron pairs. ΔGpH = -kBTln[H+] = pH × kBTln10, represents the influence of the pH value of the electrolyte, where kB is the Boltzmann constant. In this work, pH and U were assumed to be zero. The overpotential used to evaluate the catalytic activity of ORR catalysts can be obtained from the equation below: (7) η ORR = max { Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 } e + 1 . 23 ηORR is the overpotential of the ORR catalyst. ΔG1, ΔG2, ΔG3, ΔG4 represent the Gibbs free energy of each elementary reaction. Results and discussion The Mo4/3B2O2 structure modeled in this study was consistent with previous literature [45,46]. To accommodate the varying volume sizes of transition metal atoms across different periods, we introduced three O vacancies by dissociating three O atoms, as depicted in Fig. S1 [47]. The subsequent optimization of the geometric structure confirmed that all transition metal atoms were successfully embedded into these vacancies. Then, we studied the adsorption structure and active sites of O2 on the surface of TM@Mo4/3B2O2. Taking Ni@Mo4/3B2O2 as an example, two O2 molecules undergo spontaneous and continuous adsorption and dissociation processes, accompanied by negative ΔG, as illustrated in Fig. S2. This process ultimately resulted in the formation of Ni@Mo4/3B2O2–3H. Based on this reaction pathway, the TM@Mo4/3B2O2–3H structure is used as a substrate for subsequent ORR. The most stable structure is presented in Fig. 1 a. To simplify the explanation, we would use TM@Mo4/3B2O2 to replace TM@Mo4/3B2O2–3H. To verify the stability of TM@Mo4/3B2O2, we calculated the formation energies of all SACs, as depicted in Fig. 1b. It is worth noting that the formation energies of most SACs were negative, while some were positive. However, they were still lower than the formation energies of Fe-N-C (1.19 eV) and Cu-N-C (1.95 eV) SACs synthesized in the experiment, which showed good thermodynamic stability [2]. Subsequently, the thermodynamic stability of the SACs was further evaluated through ab initio molecular dynamics simulation. As shown in Fig. S3, Co@Mo4/3B2O2 and Zn@Mo4/3B2O2 were selected as representatives for AIMD due to their superior catalytic activity observed in subsequent investigations. The simulations illustrated that both catalysts exhibit remarkable stability after 5 ps at 300 K, indicating their robust thermodynamic properties. In addition, we evaluated the electronic conductivity of Co@Mo4/3B2O2 and Zn@Mo4/3B2O2, as depicted in Fig. S4. The total density of states (TDOS) and the projected density of states (PDOS) diagrams revealed that the energy levels of two SACs are continuously distributed at the Fermi level, affirming their metallic properties. During the ORR, the adsorption of O2 in the initial step is a critical stage that influences the entire reaction process. Typically, O2 can adsorb onto the catalyst surface through physical adsorption or two chemical modes, end-on adsorption and side-on adsorption. Geometric structure optimization showed that most SACs exhibit two distinct O2 adsorption structures. A lower energy implies a more stable structure, and a smaller ΔG indicates that the reaction is more thermodynamically favorable. Thus, we chose the structure with the lowest energy for subsequent ORR, as detailed in Table S1. Through the study of 25 SACs, we classified four types of O2 adsorption structures, including end-on adsorption, side-on adsorption, dissociation adsorption, and physical adsorption. These four adsorption structures are visually represented in Fig. 2 . In addition, we performed charge density difference calculations for the initial three adsorption structure types, as shown in Fig. S5. There was no electron transfer between O2 and SACs in physical adsorption. The charge density difference diagram showed that the transfer of charges is bidirectional, which represented the interaction between TM single atom and O2. In the figure, yellow and cyan represent charge increases and decreases, respectively. It was worth noting that both end-on adsorption and side-on adsorption of O2 lead to an extension of the OO bond length (1.23 Å). Furthermore, it was observed that the OO bond length increases with the increase of O2 transfer charge, as illustrated in Fig. 3 a, indicating that O2 is being activated. Finally, we summarized the characteristics of the O2 adsorption structure types observed in the 25 SACs as presented in Fig. 3b. Subsequently, we conducted the ORR catalytic performance of all SACs. In acidic conditions, the ORR typically occurs through the O2 association mechanism [48], which is characterized by the following sequence: O 2 → * O 2 → * OOH → * O → * OH → H 2 O It was worth noting that these SACs, including V, Cr, Fe, Co, Ni, Re, Rh, Cd, Os, Ir, and Pt@Mo4/3B2O2, all followed this reaction pathway, as shown in Fig. 4 a. The structural schematic diagram of the reaction steps is shown in Fig. 4b. This common reaction pathway can be simply described as O2 hydrogenation to generate *OOH, followed by hydrogenation dehydration to generate *O, further hydrogenation to generate *OH, and finally hydrogenation dehydration to restore the catalyst to its initial structure. It was worth noting that this pathway does not involve an intermediate dissociation step and remains the 4e− ORR reaction process. For Nb@Mo4/3B2O2 and Mo@Mo4/3B2O2, these two SACs would facilitate the adsorption of O2 on the surface and further dissociate into *O+*O. As depicted in Fig. 5 a, it could be seen that on the surface of Nb@Mo4/3B2O2, *O+*OH preferentially generated *OH+OH, while on the surface of Mo@Mo4/3B2O2, *O+*OH preferentially dehydrated to generate *O. The structural schematic diagram of different reaction processes of Nb@Mo4/3B2O2 and Mo@Mo4/3B2O2 is shown in Fig. 5b. As depicted in Fig. S6a, on the surface of Nb@Mo4/3B2O2, the reaction of dehydrating *O+*OH to generate *O exhibits a more positive ΔG than generating *OH+*OH. While, for Mo@Mo4/3B2O2, the situation is reversed. Here, the unique reaction pathways of these two SACs were referred to as the O2 dissociation pathway. As shown in Fig. 6 a, for Re@Mo4/3B2O2, W@Mo4/3B2O2, and Ta@Mo4/3B2O2, it can be observed that they exhibit other reaction pathways different from the two mentioned above. After optimizing the geometric structure, it was observed that the associated O2 molecules undergo dissociation into *O+*OH with the progression of the initial hydrogenation reaction. The Structural schematic diagram of reaction processes is shown in Fig. 6b. The dissimilarity between this step and the previous O2 dissociation process is attributed to the initial association of O2, but after the first reaction, it was found that the OO bond breaks and dissociates to yield *O+*OH on the surface of the substrate, as shown in Fig. S7. For Re@Mo4/3B2O2 and Ta@Mo4/3B2O2, their ORR reaction pathways are similar to that of W@Mo4/3B2O2. The dehydration reaction of *O+*OH to generate *O has a more negative ΔG compared to the generation of *OH+*OH in Fig. S6b. Here, the ORR pathways of these three SACs are named as the OOH dissociation pathway. In Fig. 7 a, it was found that for the four SACs Ti@Mo4/3B2O2, Mn@Mo4/3B2O2, Zr@Mo4/3B2O2, and Hf@Mo4/3B2O2, no dissociation of O2 was observed during the adsorption process of O2, and *OOH did not dissociate after the first hydrogenation. However, after the second hydrogenation, it was found that *OOH would dissociate into *OH+OH, indicating that these four SACs exhibit a unique reaction type. As shown in Fig. S6c, taking Zr@Mo4/3B2O2 as an example, it is also found that after hydrogenation of *OOH, the ΔG of the formation of *OH+*OH is much more negative compared to the dehydration reaction, which is opposite to the situation of the OOH dissociation pathway. Here, this pathway is named the OHOH dissociation pathway. The Structural schematic diagram of reaction processes is shown in Fig. 7b. Unlike the 4e− ORR SACs mentioned above, Zn@Mo4/3B2O2, Cu@Mo4/3B2O2, and Au@Mo4/3B2O2 exhibit a 2e− ORR process for generating H2O2, as depicted in Fig. 8 a. Taking Au@Mo4/3B2O2 as an example, it can be seen there are two ways for *OOH to undergo further hydrogenation reactions, as shown in Fig. 6d. However, the ΔG of generating *OHOH is more negative compared to the formation of *O, indicating that the dehydration process on the surface of Au@Mo4/3B2O2 is not facile. Instead, the reaction predominantly proceeds through the 2e− ORR pathway, ultimately leading to the formation of H2O2. This reaction pathway is referred to as the generation of H2O2. In addition, combined with the analysis of the adsorption structure of O2, the two SACs of Pd@Mo4/3B2O2 and Ag@Mo4/3B2O2 cannot undergo the ORR reaction. In summary, we have identified a total of six reaction pathways through geometric structure analysis and screening based on thermodynamic criteria, as summarized in Fig. 8b. During the ORR reaction, the overpotential of the electrocatalyst is the most important indicator to measure the catalytic performance of the catalyst. For better catalysts, an important criterion is a lower ORR overpotential, which is related to the most energy-consuming step in the reaction. In Tables S2 and S3, the Gibbs free energy of each step of the 23 SACs was listed, and the most energy-consuming step was marked in red. The most energy-consuming steps for 4e− ORR catalysts were summarized in Fig. S8. As shown in Fig. 9 , Co@Mo4/3B2O2 and Ru@Mo4/3B2O2 exhibit the best 4e− ORR activity, with overpotentials of 0.61 V and 0.63 V, respectively, close to the commonly used Pt catalyst (0.45 V) [44]. The adsorption-free energy of the intermediate *OOH (ΔG*OOH) was an important descriptor of 2e− ORR. In this work, Zn@Mo4/3B2O2 had the best 2e− ORR activity, with ΔG*OOH of −2.47 eV, close to the commonly used Pd catalyst (ΔG*OOH = −3.17 eV) [49]. This indicated that the three SACs studied in this project had the potential to replace traditional anode materials in PEMFCs. Based on the above analysis of adsorption and reaction path, we found that catalysts exhibiting an end-on O2 adsorption structure and following a standard ORR reaction pathway demonstrate the highest ORR activity. To further investigate the different adsorption structures of O2, diverse ORR reaction pathways, and the variation of ORR activity of 25 SACs, we calculated the electron transfer amount from the SACs to the intermediate *O2 and *OOH. The data were shown in Tables S4 and S5. Fig. S9a summarized the relationship between the electron transfer amount (Qe1) from the SACs to the intermediate *O2 and the adsorption structure. It was found that when 0.17 < Qe1 < 0.37, the adsorption structure of O2 was end-on adsorption. When 0.574 < Qe1 < 1.033, the adsorption structure changed to side-on structure, while when 1.464 < Qe1 < 1.899, it became a dissociation structure. It could be seen that the dissociation adsorption structure has the highest electron transfer number and the strongest adsorption of O2, followed by the side-on adsorption structure, and finally the end-on adsorption structure. Similarly, Fig. S9b summarized the relationship between the electron transfer amount (Qe2) from the 25 SACs to the intermediate *OOH and the ORR reaction pathway. It was found that when 0.144 < Qe2 < 0.41, the SACs follow the OOH dissociation pathway. When 0.45 < Qe2 < 0.37, the reaction mechanism changed to an OHOH dissociation mechanism, except for the Mn@Mo4/3B2O2, which follows the OHOH dissociation mechanism even though its electron transfer amount is only 0.331. In addition, when 1.13 < Qe2 < 1.475, the SACs began to follow the OOH dissociation mechanism. It could be seen that the fundamental reason for the different ORR reaction pathways is the different number of electrons obtained by intermediate *OOH from the SACs. According to the Sabatier principle, in the process of chemical reaction, the adsorption strength between the reaction intermediate and the substrate is too strong, which could lead to difficulties in desorbing the product [50]. Conversely, if the adsorption strength between the reaction intermediate and the substrate is too weak, it would hinder the substrate's ability to effectively immobilize the reactants. Therefore, effective catalytic reactions required a relatively moderate adsorption strength. So we calculated the integrated crystal orbital Hamilton population (ICOHP), which directly quantifies the bond strength between SACs and O*. By definition, a more negative ICOHP value represents a strong bonding strength. The volcanic plot with ICOHP and 4e− ORR overpotential as variables is plotted in Fig. 10 a. Co@Mo4/3B2O2 and Ru@Mo4/3B2O2 were located near the volcano peak, which was consistent with the previously calculated overpotential. The SACs with better activity can be screened according to the ICOHP value within the range of [−7.9, −5.4]. From the volcanic plot, it could be concluded that for the ORR reaction of the TM@Mo4/3B2O2 system, the essence of ORR activity lies in the ICOHP value between the SACs and the intermediate *O, which reflects the bond strength between the TM and the O atom in the intermediate *O. The stronger the bond strength, the more difficult it was for the subsequent intermediate *O to dehydrate, resulting in a decrease in ORR activity. The weaker the bond strength, the more difficult it was to adsorb O2, which also led to a decrease in ORR activity. In addition, we attempted to find and design a simple descriptor to provide atomic-scale insights into the relationship between the structure of SACs and ORR activity, aiming to summarize the rules of variation in 4e− ORR activity. As shown in Fig. S10, we investigated the relationship between the amount of electron transfer obtained by various intermediates such as *O2, *OOH, and *OH from SACs and the ORR overpotential. However, the fitting degree of all the models was not good. In previous reports, a series of descriptors involving various intrinsic properties of the catalyst, such as valence electrons (θTM) and electronegativity (λTM), have been the key factors affecting the ORR overpotential [51]. This phenomenon is attributed to the cooperative effect between the metal single atom (TM) and the Mo atoms in the substrate, resulting in the redistribution of the valence electrons of the loaded metal atoms. Additionally, electronegativity, which quantifies the electronic affinity of different atoms in forming chemical bonds, plays a significant role. Based on previous research, we propose a new descriptor as follows, (8) φ = Q OH * λ TM + λ MBene θ TM where QOH is the number of electrons obtained by the intermediate *OH from TM@Mo4/3B2O2. θTM represents the number of valence electrons of the TM. λTM and λMBene represents the electronegativity of the metal monatomic TM and MBene matrix, respectively. λMBene can be obtained through the following calculation. (9) λ MBene = n M MBene * λ M MBene + n B MBene * λ B MBene + n O MBene * λ O MBene + n H MBene * λ H MBene n M MBene + n B MBene + n O MBene + n H MBene here, n M MBene , n B MBene , n O MBene , n H MBene represent the number of atoms of the metal Mo element, B element, O element and H element in the MBene substrate, respectively. λ M MBene , λ B MBene , λ O MBene , λ H MBene represent the electronegativity of the corresponding metal Mo element, B element, O element and H element in the MBene matrix, respectively. These parameters can be easily obtained from the periodic table. As shown in Fig. 10b, the descriptor we proposed shows a good linear relationship with the 4e− ORR overpotential, with a fitting coefficient R2 of 0.9238. Therefore, our descriptors can provide guidance for the faster discovery of highly active ORR catalysts. Conclusion In summary, based on first-principles calculations, we investigated the ORR catalytic performance and reaction mechanism of TM@Mo4/3B2O2 composed of 3d, 4d, and 5d transition metal monatomic doping Mo4/3B2O2 with vacancy. Our research showed that there are four types of O2 adsorption structures and six ORR reaction pathways for 25 SACs. The number of electrons obtained from TM@Mo4/3B2O2 by the intermediates *O2 and *OOH determined the different O2 adsorption structures and reaction pathways of SACs. We found two descriptors ICOHP and φ to accurately describe the ORR catalytic activity. When the ICOHP value falls within the range of [−7.9, −5.4], the ORR activity is optimal. In addition, the lower the value of the descriptor φ, the lower the ORR overpotential. The 4e− ORR activity was found to be the best for Co@Mo4/3B2O2 (0.61 V) and Ru@Mo4/3B2O2 (0.63 V). The 2e− ORR activity was optimal for Zn@Mo4/3B2O2 (ΔG*OOH is −2.47 eV). These three SACs have the potential to serve as electrode materials for PEMFCs. Our research results not only highlight three feasible and cost-effective ORR SACs but also provide valuable guidance for finding efficient and economically feasible ORR electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: Exploring earth-abundant and inexpensive electrocatalysts to realize efficient oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is urgently desired. In this work, through first-principles calculations, we have strategically designed a series of single-atom catalysts (SACs) for ORR by immobilizing single atoms on the surface of Mo4/3B2O2, denoted as TM@Mo4/3B2O2 (TM representing 3d, 4d, and 5d transition metal atoms, excluding Tc and Hg). Significantly, for 4e− ORR, the best catalyst was Co@Mo4/3B2O2 and Ru@Mo4/3B2O2, with an overpotential of 0.61 V and 0.63 V, close to the commonly used Pt catalyst (0.45 V). In 2e− ORR, Zn@Mo4/3B2O2 had the best catalytic activity, with a ΔG*OOH of -2.47 eV, close to the commonly used Pd catalyst (ΔG*OOH = -3.17 eV). By calculating the electronic properties of SACs, it was found that the number of electrons gained by the intermediate *O2 and *OOH from the SACs determines the O2 adsorption structures and ORR reaction pathways. In addition, there are two descriptors: ICOHP and a composition descriptor which provides atomic-level insights, that were found to summarize the ORR activity rules. Our work enriches the applications of the MBenes family in catalysis, and provides feasible guidance for the design of low-cost and high-effect ORR catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Mo4/3B2O2-supported single-atom catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction
